qas.question: What can cause a person to have fake memories?

answers.text: repeatedly imagine actions that they have never performed or events that they have never experienced

qas.question: Who performed a study that showed the similarirty of imaginging doing something and then later remembering actually doing that task?
What did a similar study done by Garry find?

answers.text: researchers found that one-fourth of the students asked to imagine the four events reported that they had actually experienced such events as children

plausible_answers.text: asked participants to imagine that they performed an act (e.g., break a toothpick) and then later asked them whether they had done such a thing

qas.question: What did Goff and Roediger ask people to do in 1996?

plausible_answers.text: repeatedly imagine actions that they have never performed or events that they have never experienced could result in false memories

qas.question: What can cause a person to have fake senses?

plausible_answers.text: researchers found that one-fourth of the students asked to imagine the four events reported that they had actually experienced such events as children

qas.question: What did a similar study done by Gary Goff find?

plausible_answers.text: they were more confident that they experienced the events

qas.question: What happens when people are not asked to imagine events?
Who asked students how uncertain they were that they experienced events?

context: Interestingly, research has revealed that asking individuals to <a0_0><b4_0>repeatedly imagine actions that they have never performed or events that they have never experienced<a0_0/> could result in false memories<b4_0/>. For instance, <a1_0>Goff and Roediger<a1_0/> (1998) <b3_0>asked participants to imagine that they performed an act (e.g., break a toothpick) and then later asked them whether they had done such a thing<b3_0/>. Findings revealed that those participants who repeatedly imagined performing such an act were more likely to think that they had actually performed that act during the first session of the experiment. Similarly, <b7_0>Garry and her colleagues<b7_0/> (1996) asked college students to report how certain they were that they experienced a number of events as children (e.g., broke a window with their hand) and then two weeks later asked them to imagine four of those events. The <a2_0><b5_0>researchers found that one-fourth of the students asked to imagine the four events reported that they had actually experienced such events as children<b5_0/><a2_0/>. That is, when asked to imagine the events <b6_0>they were more confident that they experienced the events<b6_0/>.
